author: John Cross
title: Jamie Vardy admits he gets abuse at every stadium he goes to - but wouldn't change anything
text:
Public enemy No1: Vardy has lifted the lid on the abuse he gets (Photo: Getty Images Europe)   Thank you for subscribing!   
Jamie Vardy should be England’s most popular footballer because of his incredible rags to riches story. 
Vardy has gone from non-league to Premier League title winner, scored an unforgettable goal for England in Germany, reached the Champions League quarter finals and a Hollywood movie is being made of his life. 
But even though he represents hope for every aspiring footballer in the country, the Leicester striker reckons he is actually public enemy No1 with his win-at-all-costs attitude. 
Vardy, has almost become the player that every fan - barring Leicester’s, of course - loves to hate. He was called a “cheat” by Samir Nasri last week, a snake for his part in Claudio Ranieri’s downfall and admits he loves winding up opposing supporters. Vardy was blamed for getting Ranieri the sack in some quarters (Photo: Plumb Images) 
“I just get abuse at every stadium that I turn up at,” said Vardy. “To be honest, you are always going to get stick from fans. It is part and parcel of football. 
“I’m one that carries on and winds them up a bit. Do I enjoy it? Yeah, it’s just me. 
“I couldn’t tell you why I get it, but it’s part of the game. I am not really fussed about it. It’s fine by me. You’re bound to get all that stuff with it. I wouldn’t change it.” 
The title of the Vardy movie is “Fearless” and that is exactly what he believes England will have to be in the future if they are to emulate Leicester’s underdogs success of last season. Vardy tussled with Samir Nasri in the Champions League (Photo: Getty) 
Leicester was the greatest story in Premier League history and it propelled Vardy into the England squad, even scoring a spectacular back heel when the Three Lions beat Germany 3-2 in their own backyard last March. 
Sadly, that only seemed to give England false hope and expectation for the Euros, they suffered a humiliating exit to Iceland which cost Roy Hodgson his job and the players are still trying to recover. 
Vardy admits that he still struggles to explain how Leicester won the title, what went wrong at the Euros and why this season turned sour before Craig Shakespeare took over last month.
